Award.AwardTitle: ATOL: Collaborative Research: Assembling the Green Algal Tree of Life (GRAToL)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Green Algae Tree of Life (GRAToL) is a project involving the collaboration of five institutions to understand the evolutionary relationships of all of the major groups of green algae, a diverse group of more than 14,000 photosynthetic species worldwide. Green algae are abundant and play important roles in a wide variety of terrestrial and aquatic habitats, including deserts, extremely salty ponds, and coral reefs, and several species are symbiotic partners with lichens and animals. Thus, green algae are important primary producers in most ecosystems. Green algae are diverse in form - from microscopic single cells to large seaweeds - and function as important primary producers in most ecosystems. The project will employ DNA sequence data to assemble a tree of life reflecting the evolutionary history of the group. This tree will be critical for an improved classification of known species of algae as well as species that are yet to be discovered. The project will facilitate further studies of green algae genomics and evolution.

The project will train 3-4 postdoctoral researchers, several graduate students, and numerous undergraduate students in basic research on algae and genomics. New analytical tools will be developed for use by the broader scientific community. A public exhibit on the GRAToL will be produced, along with a web site containing images and other information on evolution of the group that will be of interest to educators and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Green Algae are aquatic and terrestrial photosynthetic eukaryotes that play key roles as drivers of ecosystem food webs, in symbiotic interactions with fungi and other species, and by economic and medical impacts on the lives of humans. A better understanding of diversity and relationships among green algae is needed to clarify fundamental processes underlying symbiotic associations and the assembly of entire ecosystems. Knowledge of the green algal family tree and an enhanced classification of green algae provides an important framework for understanding the evolution of key algal morphological and genetic traits. As green algae are ancestors of land plants, knowledge of their relationships and traits enhances our understanding of the emergence of land plants, including of their inherited genetic tool kits. The GRAToL project, a team of investigators (LA Lewis and PO Lewis - Univ. Connecticut, Karol - NY Botanical Garden, Lopez-Bautista - Univ. of Alabama, McCourt - Drexel Univ., Delwiche - Univ. Maryland) advanced knowledge of this important group of organisms by revealing their systematics and biodiversity. Our team focused on algae in classes Chlorophyceae and Trebouxiophyceae, using broad taxonomic sampling of species obtained from culture collections as well as newly isolated species. We collected chloroplast and mitochondrial genomic data and performed phylogenetic analysis to reveal patterns of gene and genome evolution in these algae, indicating group specific features such as codon reassignment as well as some striking differences with land plant organelle genomes. We also collect light and electron microscopic data that were used for assessing trait evolution. Our team followed up with revisionary taxonomy at many levels of classification, including many new or emended families, genera and species. Discovery of novel and deeply diverging species in Chlorophyceae and Trebouxiophyceae indicate that our understanding of the diversity of some algal groups is likely incomplete. We collaborated closely with others in the GRAToL project and performed analyses with members of the fungal TOL group (AFToL). Our work was presented at scientific conferences and published in peer reviewed journals. We provided access to all data in public repositories and deposited taxonomic vouchers in herbaria. We also developed new phylogenetic methodology and resources, including open source software. We worked closely with numerous, diverse postdoctoral, doctoral, and undergraduate trainees, enhancing their understanding of scientific inquiry and expanding their proficiency in new methods. We also enhanced their skills in collaboration and communication of their work to each other, to other scientists, and to the public.
